ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I took this for 1-credit, so my responses should we viewed accordingly.

I did not participate in the Tuesday discussion sessions so I cannot give a fair assessment of Gordon and Jena's work, but at least from all the great speakers they brought in, I think they did a fantastic job.

Overall, the course was very enjoyable, and I do think that I learned quite a lot. However, it sometimes seemed as though we covered a wide variety of topics somewhat superficially. It would have been nice to dive into some topics a little more deeply, though actually doing that within the guest-lecture-heavy structure of the class might be a challenge. One particular thing that might have been helpful would have been to have some required texts/articles other than the ones suggested by the guest speakers. This is for a few reasons--many of the guest speakers were late in providing materials, some of the readings were essentially promotional materials, and having outside readings that provide a more critical perspective/framework might create some really interesting discussion.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Exposure to a variety of different perspectives on food, some of which were entirely novel to me.
Exposure to speakers working firsthand in the area
The guest speaker series was the best part of the class -- it was great to hear from a number of practitioners working on these issues throughout the food system.

The guest speaker series was the most valuable aspect of the class. I would agree that most of the speakers gave me new insights into the food system even if they weren't what I was expecting walking in to the lecture.
The guest speakers were excellent.

The best aspects were being able to hear from practitioners in all aspects of the food system, and getting multiple inside perspectives that would be hard to get otherwise. I also appreciated how I could still get 1 credit for the course just by coming to the guest speaker sessions, which I would have done anyways since they are all very interesting.
It was really fantastic to get the chance to hear from so many guest speakers in person.
The diversity of guest lecturers and supplemented by readings.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Not cohesive, not comprehensive, and some of the speakers were fairly myopic or out of touch, beyond their academic niche -- lack of a baseline or common ground established by the professor for students and speakers -- frankly, it was obvious the professor was using the course in order to gain awareness of food issues himself, which is fine, Jena did a great job of curating and hosting herself, but I would have expected more from the professor. All of this was perfectly acceptable to most I suppose because it was low-stakes, the majority of students took the course for one easy credit -- but it does not fare well for an enormously important and broad topic that is otherwise direly under-taught and largely misunderstood by professors at FES.

A stronger reading list and more continuity from week to week would be helpful for students who do not have a background in food systems. It would also be good to have an instructor for the class who has more expertise in food -- Gordon does a great job, but it's not his field.

There was minimal feedback for the assignments and presentations. It would have been valuable to get feedback from previous assignments to make adjustments and improve. Having readings or a source textbook to assign readings from would have help with the flow and background information for the class. While I realize that the speakers do not necessarily follow the topics assigned to them, even any preview through the readings would have helped to organize the class thematically. This would also ensure that the entire class isn't necessarily reliant on the guest lecture of the week.

Somewhat by the nature of the course, driven by guest speakers with limited coordination among themselves, it was not always clear how the contents of the guest lectures connected to others or to the big picture. So a doing a brief recap of how the guest speaker's topic fits into the big picture before or during speaker introductions would be a good way to ground the contents to a bigger picture.
More practitioners

As I mentioned above, the readings and response papers probably needed improvement. It was a little frustrating to see some of the readings get uploaded late, which made it a bit of a challenge to keep to a schedule for getting response papers in. It also would have been nice to have some readings that were more theoretical.
More incentive to take it for 3 credits, like a field trip.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: The lectures and discussions complemented each other well, but it would have been helpful to have a bit more structure for the discussion sections to frame the issues.

I really enjoyed the discussion portion of the class. Without the discussions, I don't think I would have learned nearly as much because they really helped me think about what each guest speaker said more critically.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: The course was directly in line with my interests -- which is why it was an entirely worthwhile course to participate in this semester, for me -- even if the professor or class itself added little to no value to the speakers themselves.

I am very concerned and interested in food waste, as part of my overall concern with waste (focusing on industrial ecology), hence my interest in this course. But food itself is not my principal area of interest, so I appreciated having the 1-credit option so I could be exposed to the concepts and guest lectures without having to sacrifice a course in my main areas of interest.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I took the course hesitantly because I know not to expect much sophistication when it comes to the topic of food at FES -- but also because it was a very low commitment and in line with my interests -- so, I had nothing to lose.
I took this course to learn more about some of the proposed solutions for issues in the food system, and it fulfilled that goal.
I took the class to get a general overview of Global Food Systems and because of the opportunity to hear for the different guest lecturers.

I am very concerned and interested in food waste, as part of my overall concern with waste (focusing on industrial ecology), hence my interest in this course. But food itself is not my principal area of interest, so I appreciated having the 1-credit option so I could be exposed to the concepts and guest lectures without having to sacrifice a course in my main areas of interest.
I am interested in food and agriculture, and this is one of the few food-related courses taught at Yale. I had also heard good things about previous iterations of the course.
I am interested in food and it was an easy, one credit option and opportunity to learn a lot from a multitude of perspectives.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: I personally benefited from the class because I needed one credit and I appreciated many of the speakers -- I also have very low expectations when it comes to food issues at FES, so I suppose the course met these, which is not saying a lot. Knowledge gained did not necessarily surpass an equal amount of time spent alternatively, alone on the web, googling the speakers, reading articles and watching videos -- which is too bad.
Yes, It was a good introduction to a variety of problems in the food system and how they are being addressed, and introduced me to some companies and groups that I was not familiar with.
Yes, the knowledge and class discussions met my expectations. The class was a great overview of food systems, the guest lecturers were a unique aspect of the class that worked smoothly

I greatly enjoyed learning from a diverse range of speakers with different focus areas and experience. Some speakers were more interesting to me than others, but all were still interesting and I learned a lot from each one.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Subject matter is broad and important -- likely of interest to anyone with limited knowledge of, but interest in, food issues -- commitment is so low the course is entirely worth taking. Anticipate that the level of sophistication in thinking about food will be woefully elemental, and the execution of the course will be a bit fumbly and poor, or at least it would have been this year were it not for Jena's active role. Spending time over lunch after the class with interesting speakers is perhaps the most promising value-add in taking this course.
encourage to take

The course provides a good introduction to a number of topics and is very driven by whoever is TAing the class, as they design it. Talk to the TA to find out more about what specifically will be covered each term.

If you have any interest in food issues, this course is a great way to get exposed to leading practitioners and ideas in the food system. And the 1-credit option is very low-commitment but high reward, so I would definitely recommend it!
Mostly interesting, some very good contacts can be made through the visiting speakers
